slide.title: Welcome to ClearSky !
lines: With the next few pages we’ll try and help you setup your mliti-pollutions sensing system.
Depending on your familiarity with the Raspberry Pi, the process may take up to 15 minutes.

slide.title: Setting up the Raspberry Pi
lines: First up, you need to get a Raspberry Pi with internet connectivity.
• The latest model (Raspberry Pi 3B) comes equipped with Wifi and ethernet
• The Pi 0 also comes with Wifi, but is slower
• Finally, you can also buy a Wifi adapter and plug it into any Raspberry Pi
We recommend heading over to https://projects.raspberrypi.org for a quick tutorial on getting started.

slide.title: Setting up the sensors
lines: To have an accurate estimate of the air quality in your area, you’ll need to buy sensors for the most common types of pollutants.
For an out-of-the-box solution, use the following sensors :
SDS011 : details
DHT22 : details
MQ2 : details
A minimal amount of coding is necessary if you wish to add differents sensors, but we’ll be glad to help at https://github.com/capteurPollutions/Embedded.

slide.title: Setting up ClearSky
lines: Please clone or download from github in your Raspberry Pi :
• mkdir ~/ClearSky
• cd ~/ClearSky
• git clone https://github.com/CapteursPollution/Embedded
• cd Embedded/Installation/RaspberryPi/ && sudo sh setup.sh
After restarting, your Raspberry should now start reading the data from the sensors.
Next up, configuring the mobile app to visualize this data !

slide.title: Addresses
lines: What’s the IP Address of the Raspberry Pi (How to get it ? ) : INPUT
Help us spread knowledge and data about Air Quality ! We’re building a map of the data collected by our users and accessible to everyone (data is anonymized).
Do you wish to upload the data collected by your system : TOGGLE YES NO
Optionally, you may want to use another server to upload your data to : INPUT SERVER ADD
